answers.answer: During pregnancy your TSH should be target between 1-2. As I know hypothyroidism in pregnancy can affect the neural development of the fetus. If hypothyroidism isn't treated it can be responsible for elevation of prolactin and that can be responsible for infertility...., but I think there is more miscarrieges the first 3 months (because of the neural development of the fetus that is affected) with not treated Hypothyroidism  but if you control it before pregnancy it isn't a problem...TSH of 5 is a subclinical hypothyroidism and I think it should be treated (as you have been doing) if you want to get pregnan (must target your TSH to 1 -2 ) . May be some people overhere have practical expierence about this and can give you some more advices.

question: I was diagnosed many years ago with Hashimoto's Thyroiditis and, based on my doctor's recommendation, left it untreated.  Later, I became pregnant for the first time and gave birth to a healthy boy.  My pregnancy did have some complications with preeclampsia resulted in c-section delivery 3 weeks from due date.  Since this time, I have had two miscarriages during the first trimester.  I would like to begin attempting pregnancy again.  My fertility specialist gave me a script for Synthroid 75mcg, after my suggestion regarding high TSH levels (approx 5).  Do you recommend Synthroid for TSH levels in this range coupled with prior miscarriages?  Any other suggestions?  I want to carry a healthy baby to term and beyond...
title: TSH and Miscarriage
